metadata.title: Effects of promoters on the performance of a VO<ce:italic><ce:inf loc=post>x</ce:inf></ce:italic>/SiO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> catalyst for the oxidation of methane to formaldehyde

Table 4 Catalyst BET specific surface area (m2 g−1) Pore volume (cm3 g−1) Average pore size (nm) SiO2 475 1.7 7.1 V(2)/SiO2 461 1.2 5.7 V(2)/Ga(1)/SiO2 472 1.5 6.5 V(5)/SiO2 386 1.1 5.8 V(5)/Ga(1)/SiO2 395 1.1 5.8 Effects of promoters on the performance of a VO x /SiO2 catalyst for the oxidation of methane to formaldehyde Katsuya Shimura ⁎ Tadahiro Fujitani Interdisciplinary Research Center for Catalytic Chemistry, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), 1-1-1 Higashi, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305-8565, Japan Interdisciplinary Research Center for Catalytic Chemistry National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST) 1-1-1 Higashi Tsukuba Ibaraki 305-8565 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The effects of promoters on the performance of a VO x /SiO2 catalyst were investigated with the goal of increasing its catalytic activity for the oxidation of methane to formaldehyde. Fourteen types of metal oxides (MO x , M = Ga, In, Y, Al, Bi, Zr, La, Zn, W, Mg, Mo, Ti, Ce, and Ca) were tested as promoters. Among them, Ga2O3, In2O3, Y2O3, and Al2O3 substantially increased the methane conversion rate and the formaldehyde yield, whereas MgO, MoO x , TiO2, CeO2, and CaO were less effective as promoters. The catalytic activity also depended on the amount of the promoter and the method by which it was loaded onto the support. The highest activity was obtained over VO x /Ga2O3/SiO2 (V loading, 2–3 wt%; Ga loading, 0.1–0.5 wt%) prepared by a sequential impregnation method (Ga loaded first and then V): under the standard reaction conditions (reaction temperature, 590 °C; gas hourly space velocity, 60,000 L kg−1 h−1; CH4/O2 ratio, 2), the formaldehyde yield over this catalyst was 2.1 times that over bare VO x /SiO2. Reactions over the VO x /Ga2O3/SiO2 catalyst and the bare VO x /SiO2 catalyst showed different kinetics, indicating that Ga2O3 altered the properties of the active VO x sites. Catalyst characterization by means of X-ray diffraction and temperature-programmed reduction under H2 suggested that the high activity of VO x /Ga2O3/SiO2 was due to the promoter’s having increased the reducibility of the active VO x species without decreasing their dispersion. Keywords Methane Partial oxidation Formaldehyde synthesis Vanadium oxide catalyst Promoter 1 Introduction Because of growing concerns about the environment and energy sustainability, the development of alternatives to oil is highly desirable. Methane (CH4) is one possibility. Methane is an abundant natural resource [1], and its combustion produces less CO2, NO x , and SO x than combustion of oil or coal. Furthermore, CH4 is the main component of biogas, which is a renewable resource [1]. Although CH4 is a promising alternative to oil, its use as a chemical feedstock is limited and more than 90% of the CH4 is burned to create the thermal energy and the electricity [1]. Methane is very stable, and activation of its CH bond requires considerable energy input (high temperature and pressure). Furthermore, because the target products are generally more reactive than CH4, suppressing reactions of the products is difficult. Current technology for producing fuels and chemicals from CH4 involves an energy-intensive, uneconomical multistep process [2,3]. First, CH4 is converted into syngas (a mixture of H2 and CO) by steam reforming over a heterogeneous Ni catalyst. Steam reforming of CH4 is thermodynamically unfavorable and typically requires temperatures exceeding 800 °C even in the presence of catalysts, and therefore the reforming reaction accounts for 60–70% of the capital cost of the multistep process [3]. Next, syngas is transformed into methanol and a mixture of hydrocarbons by methanol synthesis and Fischer–Tropsch synthesis at high pressures (2–10 MPa). To promote the utilization of CH4 as a chemical feedstock, we must develop a more efficient and economical process for CH4 conversion. Direct conversion of CH4 into liquid fuels and chemicals is one promising method because the energy-intensive steam reforming step can be avoided. For this purpose, various reactions have been explored, including partial oxidation of CH4 to oxygenated products (e.g., methanol and formaldehyde) [4–7], oxidative coupling of CH4 to C2 compounds [7,8], and CH4 aromatization [8,9]. However, these reactions are inefficient, and none of them are practical enough for industrial applications. Therefore, the development of highly active catalysts that can selectively convert CH4 into the desired products under mild conditions is necessary for the commercialization of processes for direct CH4 conversion. Direct conversion of CH4 to formaldehyde (HCHO) with O2 is an attractive option, and various catalysts, such as SiO2-supported metal oxides (e.g., VO x /SiO2, MoO x /SiO2, and FeO x /SiO2) and composite metal oxides (e.g., FePO4 and Fe2(MnO4)3), have been developed for this purpose [4–7]. Among them, VO x /SiO2 and MoO x /SiO2 show relatively high activity. As the support of VO x and MoO x catalysts, the inert SiO2 support has been reported to be more suitable than acidic or basic supports (e.g., Al2O3, TiO2, and SnO2) [10–12]. In addition, highly dispersed active metal oxide species are necessary for selective formation of HCHO because aggregated species promote oxidation of HCHO to CO and CO2 [13]. Thus, two main approaches have been used for the development of highly active catalysts. One approach involves the use of mesoporous SiO2 with a large surface area and a well-ordered pore structure (e.g., MCM-41 and SBA-15) instead of amorphous SiO2 as the support material [14–17]. The other involves improvement in the method for catalyst preparation (e.g., the use of sol–gel, ion exchange, and grafting methods), because the conventional impregnation method is not always effective for isolating the active species [18–25]. However, the HCHO yield is still only 3–4% at best, which is far from practical [1]. Therefore, new approaches must also be considered. In the present study, we examined the effects of promoter addition on the performance of a VO x /SiO2 catalyst for the oxidation of CH4 to HCHO by oxygen. The addition of a metal oxide as a second component is known to improve the activity of various supported metal and metal oxide catalysts. However, as far as we know, there have been only a few studies of the effects of promoter addition on catalysts for partial oxidation of CH4 [26]. Here, we report that the catalytic activity of VO x /SiO2 was greatly improved by the addition of a small amount of Ga2O3 as a promoter. We systematically examined the catalytic behavior of the VO x /Ga2O3/SiO2 catalyst, as well as the kinetics of the oxidation reaction, and we discuss the role of the Ga2O3 promoter in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Using a sequential impregnation method, we prepared promoter-modified VO x /SiO2 catalysts, designated V(a)/M(b)/SiO2, where M, a, and b designate the metal oxide promoter, the V loading (wt%), and the metal oxide promoter loading (wt%), respectively. First, M/SiO2 was prepared from SiO2 (P-6, Fuji Silysia) powders and an aqueous solution of metal ion M by an impregnation method. The precursors of the metal oxide promoters were Ga(NO3)3·nH2O (Ga content, 18.9%), In(NO3)3·3H2O, Y(NO3)3·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O, La(NO3)3·6H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, (NH4)10W12O41·5H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Ti(C3H7O)2(C5H7O2)2, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, and Ca(NO3)2·4H2O. The purity of these chemicals was greater than 98%. The loading of each metal was typically 1 wt%. The impregnated powders were dried at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined in air at 600 °C for 4 h. Then V was loaded onto the M/SiO2 by means of an impregnation method using NH4VO3 (99.5%, Wako) as the V precursor. The V loading was varied from 1 to 5 wt%. Finally, the obtained powders were dried at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined in air at 600 °C for 4 h. V/SiO2 catalysts modified with the Ga2O3 promoter were also prepared by a reverse sequential impregnation method and by a co-impregnation method. For the former, catalysts were prepared by means of the procedure described above for sequential impregnation except that impregnation with V was the first step and impregnation with Ga was the second step. In the co-impregnation method, the SiO2 was impregnated simultaneously with V and Ga. The resulting powders were dried at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined in air at 600 °C for 4 h. The catalysts prepared by reverse sequential impregnation and co-impregnation are designated as Ga/V/SiO2 and V + Ga/SiO2, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the catalysts were measured at −196 °C with an ASAP 2020 system (Micromeritics). Prior to the measurements, the samples (0.15 g) were out-gassed at 400 °C for 4 h under vacuum. Specific surface areas were obtained by applying the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) model for adsorption in a relative pressure range of 0.05–0.30. Total pore volumes were calculated from the amount of N2 vapor adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.99. The pore size distributions of the catalysts were determined by means of the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda model from the desorption branches of the nitrogen isotherms. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded at room temperature on a D8 ADVANCE diffractometer (Bruker AXS) with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA). Temperature-programmed reduction under H2 (H2-TPR) was carried out with a BELCAT-B chemisorption analyzer (BEL Japan Inc.). Calcined catalyst (0.10 g) was mounted in a quartz cell and heated to 800 °C in a flow of 5% H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The effluent gas was passed through a trap containing 5A molecular sieves to remove the produced water before the gas reached the thermal conductivity detector. 2.3 Typical procedures for catalytic reactions Catalytic reactions were performed in a fixed-bed down-flow quartz reactor operated at atmosphere pressure. Catalyst (0.10 g) was loaded into the reactor along with quartz wool, which was placed before and after the catalyst bed. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was pretreated in a flow of 20% O2/He (50 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 30 min and then purged with He (50 mL min−1) for 30 min. The reaction was initiated by introducing the reaction gas mixture at a fixed temperature. Typically, the reaction was carried out at 590 °C for 6 h. The reaction gas mixture was composed of CH4 (40%), O2 (20%), and He (40%), and the total flow rate was 100 mL min−1. The effluent gas (containing CH4, O2, CO, and CO2) was analyzed by online gas chromatography (GC) on an instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a column of 5A molecular sieves. The liquid products (methanol and HCHO) were collected in a water-filled trap at 0 °C and analyzed by GC-TCD on an instrument equipped with a Porapak T column. We conducted multiple catalytic reaction tests on each sample and confirmed the reproducibility of the experiment. Experimental error of product yield was typically smaller than 0.05%. The carbon mass balance exceeded 95% for all experiments. No obvious deactivation was observed for any of the catalysts. Results obtained 6 h after the start of the reaction were used for the discussion below. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of additive type on V/SiO2 activity We prepared 14 types of V(5)/M(1)/SiO2 catalysts, each modified with a different promoter, and we compared their catalytic activities for the oxidation of CH4 to HCHO under the standard reaction condition (reaction temperature, 590 °C; total flow rate, 100 mL min−1; reactant gas composition, 2:1:2 CH4/O2/He; catalyst weight, 0.10 g). We obtained HCHO, CO, and CO2 as the main products regardless of the type of catalyst and reaction conditions, and the yields of methanol and C2 compounds were less than 0.01%. We also confirmed that the catalytic activity did not decrease for 10 h, although we have not conducted the further long-time catalytic reaction test. When bare SiO2 was used as the catalyst, oxidation of CH4 to HCHO proceeded selectively, but the yield of HCHO was quite low (<0.1%; Table 1 , entry 1). Adding 5 wt% V to the SiO2 support increased both CH4 conversion and HCHO yield (entry 2): the HCHO yield over V(5)/SiO2 was 4.7 times that over the SiO2 support. The activities of the V(5)/M(1)/SiO2 catalysts varied substantially depending on the promoter. When Ga2O3, In2O3, Y2O3, Al2O3, BiO x , ZrO2, or La2O3 was used as the promoter, both CH4 conversion and HCHO yield were higher than the corresponding yields for V(5)/SiO2 (entries 3–9). In contrast, the addition of MgO, MoO x , TiO2, CeO2, or CaO resulted in markedly lower catalytic activities compared with that of V(5)/SiO2 (entries 12–16). The activities of V/Zn/SiO2 and V/W/SiO2 were almost the same as that of the bare V/SiO2 catalyst (entries 10 and 11). The highest activity was obtained with V(5)/Ga(1)/SiO2 (entry 3), the use of which resulted in a HCHO yield that was 1.8 times that with bare V(5)/SiO2. It should be noted that the activity of V(5)/Ga(1)/SiO2 catalyst was greater than the sum of the activities of V(5)/SiO2 and Ga(1)/SiO2 catalysts. This shows that high activity of V/Ga/SiO2 catalyst is due to the synergy effect of VO x and Ga2O3. Ga2O3 did not show the negligible activity for the partial oxidation of methane but it could greatly improve the catalytic activity of VO x . The results in Table 1 also show that as CH4 conversion increased, HCHO selectivity decreased and CO x selectivity increased. This is because CO x was produced by the oxidation of HCHO, as previously proposed by various research groups [10–14 27]. In other words, as CH4 conversion increased, oxidation of HCHO was promoted, resulting in the decrease in HCHO selectivity. 3.2 Optimization of the V/Ga/SiO2 catalyst Next, we optimized the conditions for preparation of the V/Ga/SiO2 catalyst, which was the most active of the catalysts listed in Table 1. We investigated the influence of V loading on CH4 conversion, HCHO selectivity, and HCHO yield over the V/SiO2 and V/Ga(0.5)/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 1 ). As the V loading on V/SiO2 was increased from 0 to 5 wt%, CH4 conversion increased until the loading reached 3 wt%, and then the conversion remained unchanged as the loading was increased further (Fig. 1A). In contrast, over V/Ga(0.5)/SiO2, the dependence of CH4 conversion on V loading showed volcano-type behavior, with maximum CH4 conversion at a V loading of 3 wt% (Fig. 1B). In contrast, for both series of catalysts, HCHO selectivity decreased monotonically with increasing V loading. HCHO yield also showed volcano-type dependence, with the highest value being obtained at a V loading of 3 wt%. The decrease in HCHO yield at loadings from 3 to 5 wt% was probably due to a decrease in the number of active sites resulting from the aggregation of VO x species. In addition, the presence of VO x aggregates can be expected to have promoted oxidation of HCHO, resulting in a decrease in HCHO selectivity [13]. The HCHO yield over the best catalyst, V(3)/Ga(0.5)/SiO2, was 2 times that over the bare V(3)/SiO2 catalyst. We also investigated the influence of Ga loading on CH4 conversion, HCHO selectivity, and HCHO yield over the V(2)/Ga/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 2 ). As the Ga loading was increased from 0 to 1 wt%, CH4 conversion increased sharply until a loading of 0.1 wt%, was nearly constant in the range from 0.1 to 0.5 wt%, and then decreased again above 0.5 wt%. HCHO selectivity decreased with increasing Ga loading up to 0.1 wt% and then remained nearly constant as the loading was increased further. The HCHO yield showed volcano-type dependence, and the highest value was obtained over the V(2)/Ga(0.3)/SiO2 catalyst. On the basis of these results, we propose that a low Ga loading improved the properties of the active sites without decreasing their number, and thereby increased the catalytic activity. However, addition of too much of the Ga2O3 promoter covered the surface of the active VO x species, resulting in a decrease of catalytic activity. We also used three different methods to prepare Ga(0.5)-doped V(2)/SiO2 catalysts and then compared the activities of the resulting catalysts for oxidation of CH4 to HCHO: specifically, a V(2)/Ga(0.5)/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by the sequential impregnation method (Ga was loaded first and then V); a V(2)+Ga(0.5)/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by the co-impregnation method; and a Ga(0.5)/V(2)/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by the reverse sequential impregnation method (V was loaded first step and then Ga). All three catalysts showed higher catalytic activity than the bare V(2)/SiO2 catalyst (Table 2 ), but the activity depended on the preparation method. The V(2)/Ga(0.5)/SiO2 catalyst showed the highest activity, and the activity of the V(2)+Ga(0.5)/SiO2 catalyst was almost the same as that of the Ga(0.5)/V(2)/SiO2 catalyst. The relatively low activity of the latter two catalysts was probably due to coverage of portions of the surface of the VO x species by the Ga2O3 promoter. The results of these experiments also suggest that the active sites of the V/Ga/SiO2 catalyst were surface VO x species and that the Ga2O3 promoter improved their properties, such as their dispersion and redox activity. Eventually, the V(2)/Ga(0.3)/SiO2 catalyst showed the highest HCHO yield (1.10%) among the catalysts examined. This value was 2.1 times that over the bare V/SiO2 catalyst (0.53%). 3.3 Kinetics of partial oxidation catalyzed by V(2)/Ga(0.3)/SiO2 To clarify the role of the Ga2O3 promoter, we studied the kinetics of reactions catalyzed by V(2)/Ga(0.3)/SiO2 (Table 3 and Figs. 3–5 ). First, we examined the effects of CH4 concentration on CH4 conversion rate and product selectivity when the other reaction conditions were kept constant (reaction temperature, 590 °C; total flow rate, 100 mL min−1; 20% O2; catalyst weight, 0.10 g). The CH4 conversion rate increased linearly with increasing CH4 concentration, suggesting that the reaction order with respect to CH4 was 1.0 (Fig. 3A). This result is consistent with previously reported results for VO x /SiO2 and VO x /mesoporous SiO2 catalysts [5,14,22,27,28]. The product selectivity was independent of CH4 concentration and was nearly constant in the CH4 concentration range of 20–50% (Fig. 3B). This result is reasonable because CH4 conversion was essentially unchanged in this concentration range (Table 3, entries 1–6). Next, we examined the effects of O2 concentration on CH4 conversion rate and product selectivity. We found that the CH4 conversion rate increased at O2 concentrations of <10% and then decreased as the concentration was increased further (Fig. 4A and Table 3, entries 7–12). The reaction order was estimated to be 0.5 at low O2 concentrations (<10%) and −0.7 at high O2 concentrations (>10%). This result differs from previously reported results for VO x /SiO2 and VO x /mesoporous SiO2 catalysts; that is, the CH4 conversion rates over these catalysts remain almost unchanged when the O2 concentration is increased, and the reaction order with respect to O2 is 0–0.3 [5,14,22,27,28]. The mechanism of the oxidation of CH4 to HCHO over VO x /SiO2 is generally accepted to involve initial oxidation of CH4 by the lattice oxygen atoms of active VO x species followed by replenishment of the lattice oxygen by O2. This replenishment is very fast, and the rate-determining step of this reaction is the activation of CH4 by active oxygen species [5]. Therefore, variation of the CH4 conversion rate with O2 concentration over VO x /SiO2 catalysts is typically minimal. However, we found that the activity of the V/Ga/SiO2 catalyst depended strongly on O2 concentration (Fig. 4A). It is particularly surprising that at high O2 concentrations, the reaction order was negative despite the fact that the reaction was an oxidative one. We suggest that the Ga2O3 promoter may have changed the adsorption behavior of reactants at the active sites. That is, Ga2O3 may have excessively promoted the adsorption of O2 and inhibited CH4 adsorption, resulting in the decrease of catalytic activity at high O2 concentrations. Another possibility is that O2 concentration may have influenced the electronic state of Ga2O3. At an O2 concentration of around 10%, the electronic state of Ga2O3 may be optimal for producing the maximum promotional effect. In contrast, O2 concentration had little influence on product selectivity (Fig. 4B), although the HCHO selectivity was slightly lower and the CO selectivity slightly higher when the CH4 conversion rate was high. This behavior was attributed to promotion of HCHO oxidation at higher CH4 conversion rates, as mentioned above. We also examined the effects of temperature on CH4 oxidation reactions over V(2)/SiO2 and V(2)/Ga(0.3)/SiO2. For both catalysts, CH4 conversion increased, HCHO selectivity decreased, and HCHO yield increased as the reaction temperature was increased (Fig. 5 and Table 3, entries 13–17). HCHO selectivity decreased by about 60% at the temperature rise of 35–38 °C. This is because oxidation of HCHO was promoted at higher CH4 conversion rates. However, the HCHO yield over the V(2)/Ga(0.3)/SiO2 catalyst was much higher than that over the V(2)/SiO2 catalyst. For example, the HCHO yield over V(2)/Ga(0.3)/SiO2 was 1.22% at 597 °C, whereas that over V(2)/SiO2 was 0.68% at 628 °C. We also evaluated the relationship between HCHO selectivity and CH4 conversion (Fig. 6 ) and found that the V(2)/Ga(0.3)/SiO2 catalyst exhibited higher HCHO selectivity than the V(2)/SiO2 catalyst at the same CH4 conversion. This result clearly shows that Ga2O3 improved HCHO selectivity as well as CH4 conversion. Arrhenius plots showed linear relationships for both catalysts in the examined temperature range (Fig. 7 ), and the activation energy for the reaction over the V(2)/SiO2 catalyst was calculated to be 274 kJ mol−1, which is similar to previously reported values for reactions over VO x /SiO2 and VOx/mesoporous SiO2 catalysts (227–281 kJ mol−1) [5,14,22,27]. However, the activation energy over the V(2)/Ga(0.3)/SiO2 catalyst (350 kJ mol−1) differed from that over the bare V(2)/SiO2 catalyst, which clearly shows that Ga2O3 altered the properties of the active sites. 3.4 Characterization of V/Ga/SiO2 catalysts and role of the Ga2O3 promoter To gain further insight into the role of Ga2O3, we characterized the V/M/SiO2 catalysts by means of N2 adsorption, XRD, and H2-TPR. BET specific surface areas, pore volumes, and average pore sizes for SiO2, V/SiO2, and V/Ga(1)/SiO2 are listed in Table 4 . All three parameters tended to decrease with increasing V loading. In particular, the BET specific surface area decreased considerably when the V loading was increased from 2 to 5 wt%, probably because aggregated VO x particles blocked the entrances to the pores of the SiO2 support. In contrast, the pore structures of the V/SiO2 catalysts were essentially the same before and after addition of Ga2O3, indicating that the promoter had little influence on the mass transfer of the reactants and products. In other words, the promoter mainly influenced the structure of the active VO x species. We also measured the BET specific surface areas, pore volumes, and average pore sizes of the Ga(0.5)-modified V(2)/SiO2 catalysts, which were prepared by three different method (Table S1). BET specific surface of the Ga(0.5)/V(2)/SiO2 catalyst was a little lower than that of the V(2)/Ga(0.5)/SiO2 and V(2)+Ga(0.5)/SiO2 catalysts. Among the catalysts listed in Table 1, V(5)/SiO2 and seven of the V(5)/M(1)/SiO2 catalysts (M = Ga, Y, Al, Zr, La, Mg, Ca) were subjected to XRD analysis (Fig. 8 ). As mentioned above, the activities of these V(5)/M(1)/SiO2 catalysts and the bare catalyst decreased in the following order: Ga > Y > Al > Zr > La > bare > Mg > Ca. The XRD patterns of V/Ga/SiO2, V/SiO2, V/Mg/SiO2, and V/Ca/SiO2 showed only a broad peak characteristic of amorphous SiO2, indicating that both the VO x species and the promoter were highly dispersed on the SiO2 support. The XRD pattern of the V/La/SiO2 catalyst showed peaks for La2O3, although no peaks for V compounds were observed. In the XRD patterns of V/Y/SiO2, V/Al/SiO2, and V/Zr/SiO2, peaks for V compounds such as VO2 and V2O5 were observed, suggesting that the dispersions of VO x species over these three catalysts were lower than that over the other V/M/SiO2 catalysts. The XRD results show that the addition of a small amount of a metal oxide promoter had a large influence on the dispersion of VO x species. It is interesting to note that the highly active catalysts, such as V/Y/SiO2 and V/Al/SiO2, had aggregated VO x particles, whereas catalysts with low activity, such as V/Mg/SiO2 and V/Ca/SiO2, had highly dispersed VO x species. This result seems inconsistent with the general consensus that the active sites of VO x /SiO2 catalysts for partial oxidation of CH4 are highly dispersed VO x species [5–7]. This inconsistency suggests that other factors influenced the catalytic activity. The H2-TPR profiles of the V(5)/M(1)/SiO2 and V(2)/Ga/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . The peak shapes and positions varied considerably depending on the type of additive and its loading. In the H2 profiles of the V(5)/SiO2 catalysts, an intense main peak was observed at approximately 510 °C, and small shoulder peaks were observed at 550–750 °C (Fig. 9A). It is generally accepted that the main peak originates from the reduction of highly dispersed monomeric and/or low-oligomeric VO x species and that the shoulder peaks at the higher temperature side are due to the reduction of polymeric VO x species [13,14,16,22,24,29,30]. The positions of the main peak for the V/SiO2 catalysts modified with Y2O3, ZrO2, and La2O3 were almost the same as that for the bare V/SiO2 catalyst. However, the positions of the peak for the V/Ga/SiO2 and V/Al/SiO2 catalysts were observed at lower temperature than that for the bare V/SiO2 catalyst. This difference indicates that Ga2O3 and Al2O3 promoted the reduction of active VO x species. Furthermore, in the H2-TPR profiles of the V(2)/Ga/SiO2 catalysts, the position of the main reduction peak shifted to lower temperature with increasing Ga loading (Fig. 9B). In contrast, the addition of MgO or CaO shifted the main peak to higher temperature, indicating that MgO and CaO hampered reduction of the active VO x species. H2-TPR profiles of VO x /SiO2 catalysts can also be used to estimate the dispersion of VO x species. The calculation of VO x dispersion using H2-TPR was proposed by Koranne et al. in 1994 [29] and has been used in various research papers [10,13,22,31]. In this method, VO x dispersion can be easily calculated by dividing the area of the low-temperature peak corresponding to the highly dispersed VO x species by the total area of the H2-TPR profile. Furthermore, it was confirmed that VO x dispersion measured by H2-TPR well consisted with that measured by other techniques such as high temperature oxygen chemisorption [13,29]. In this way, the dispersions of VO x species for the V(5)/M(1)/SiO2 catalysts were estimated to be 57–83% (Table 1). The VO x dispersions of the V(5)/SiO2 catalysts modified with Y2O3, Al2O3, and ZrO2 were lower than that of the bare V(5)/SiO2 catalyst. This difference is consistent with the XRD results (Fig. 8). In contrast, the VO x dispersions of the V(5)/SiO2 catalysts modified with Ga2O3, La2O3, MgO, and CaO were higher than that of the bare V(5)/SiO2 catalyst. The VO x dispersions of the V(2)/Ga/SiO2 (Ga loading, 0–1 wt%) catalysts were calculated to be 76–85% and did not vary with Ga loading. The H2-TPR results show that Ga2O3 improved both the dispersion and the reducibility of the active VO x species. We also measured the H2-TPR profiles of the Ga(0.5)-modified V(2)/SiO2 catalysts, which were prepared by three different method. The preparation method influenced the reducibility and dispersion of active VO x species (Fig. S1 and Table S1). VO x dispersion of the Ga(0.5)/V(2)/SiO2 catalyst was obviously lower than that of the V(2)/Ga(0.5)/SiO2 and V(2)+Ga(0.5)/SiO2 catalysts. We will now discuss the relationship between the structure of the active VO x species and the activity of the V/M/SiO2 catalyst, on the basis of the H2-TPR results. CH4 conversion over the V(5)/M(1)/SiO2 catalyst was plotted against the temperature for reduction of the highly dispersed VO x species, which was estimated from the peak top temperature in the H2-TPR profile (Fig. 9A). CH4 conversion tended to increase with decreasing reduction temperature (Fig. 10 A). A plot of CH4 conversion against VO x dispersion (Fig. 10B) shows no clear correlation. Therefore, we suggest that the high activity of the V/Ga/SiO2 catalyst can be attributed to an increase in the reducibility of active VO x species rather than to the enhancement of VO x dispersion. As described above, the mechanism of the oxidation of CH4 to HCHO over VO x /SiO2 involves oxidation of CH4 by the lattice oxygen atoms of active VO x species and subsequent oxidation of the reduced VO x species by O2 in the next step. Addition of Ga2O3 likely enhanced the reactivity of the lattice oxygen atoms of the active VO x species and promoted CH4 oxidation in the first step, resulting in the high overall catalytic activity. Further studies are now being carried out in our laboratory to clarify the role of the Ga2O3 promoter and to prepare more-active V/Ga/SiO2 catalysts. 4 Conclusions The effects of promoter addition on the performance of a VO x /SiO2 catalyst for the oxidation of CH4 to HCHO by O2 were studied. Fourteen types of metal oxides (MO x , M = Ga, In, Y, Al, Bi, Zr, La, Zn, W, Mg, Mo, Ti, Ce, and Ca) were employed as promoters. Of these, Ga2O3, In2O3, Y2O3, and Al2O3 markedly increased CH4 conversion and HCHO yield, whereas MgO, MoO x , TiO2, CeO2, and CaO decreased the catalytic activity. Catalytic activity was also influenced by the loading of the promoter and the method by which it was added to the catalyst; a catalyst prepared by the sequential impregnation method (promoter loaded first and then V) showed higher activity than catalysts prepared by co-impregnation and reverse sequential impregnation (V loaded first and then the promoter). The optimum promoter loading was as low as 0.1–0.5 wt%. These results indicate that promoters should be deposited in such a way that they do not cover the surface of the active VO x species. The HCHO yield obtained with the best catalyst, V(2–3 wt%)/Ga(0.1–0.5 wt%)/SiO2, was 2.1 times that obtained with bare VO x /SiO2 under the standard reaction conditions (reaction temperature, 590 °C; gas hourly space velocity, 60,000 L kg−1 h−1; CH4/O2 ratio, 2). Kinetics studies and characterization of the catalysts suggest that Ga2O3 increased the reducibility of the active VO x species without reducing their dispersion, resulting in the high catalytic activity of the V/Ga/SiO2 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The effects of promoters on the performance of a VO x /SiO2 catalyst were investigated with the goal of increasing its catalytic activity for the oxidation of methane to formaldehyde. Fourteen types of metal oxides (MO x , M = Ga, In, Y, Al, Bi, Zr, La, Zn, W, Mg, Mo, Ti, Ce, and Ca) were tested as promoters. Among them, Ga2O3, In2O3, Y2O3, and Al2O3 substantially increased the methane conversion rate and the formaldehyde yield, whereas MgO, MoO x , TiO2, CeO2, and CaO were less effective as promoters. The catalytic activity also depended on the amount of the promoter and the method by which it was loaded onto the support. The highest activity was obtained over VO x /Ga2O3/SiO2 (V loading, 2–3 wt%; Ga loading, 0.1–0.5 wt%) prepared by a sequential impregnation method (Ga loaded first and then V): under the standard reaction conditions (reaction temperature, 590 °C; gas hourly space velocity, 60,000 L kg−1 h−1; CH4/O2 ratio, 2), the formaldehyde yield over this catalyst was 2.1 times that over bare VO x /SiO2. Reactions over the VO x /Ga2O3/SiO2 catalyst and the bare VO x /SiO2 catalyst showed different kinetics, indicating that Ga2O3 altered the properties of the active VO x sites. Catalyst characterization by means of X-ray diffraction and temperature-programmed reduction under H2 suggested that the high activity of VO x /Ga2O3/SiO2 was due to the promoter’s having increased the reducibility of the active VO x species without decreasing their dispersion.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of promoters on the performance of a VO x /SiO2 catalyst for the oxidation of methane to formaldehyde
